image.altText: Mortar board sitting on a pile of money

items.synopsis: While the merger of UniSA and the University of Adelaide is being spruiked by the SA government as a once-in-a-generation opportunity for the state and its education sector, it is far from a fait accompli.

title.children: The unis might be in unison, but is the SA merger deal a unicorn?

image.altText: Greyhound legs and lower torso while the animal is running.

items.synopsis: Animal welfare authorities say they are unable to pursue criminal charges in relation to footage showing two SA men using live rabbits as baits to train greyhounds, due to legal issues with key evidence.

title.children: Greyhound trainers can't face charges because live baiting video was obtained 'illegally', RSPCA says

image.altText: A white truck damaged and rolled onto its side on a road.

items.synopsis: A truck has crashed into a tree and a light pole before rolling onto its side in Adelaide's north.

title.children: Driver escapes injury after truck veers off road and hits light pole

image.altText: A photograph, taken from above, of dozens of umbrellas and sunlounges on a sandy beach.

items.synopsis: On this Greek island, going to many beaches now comes with a price tag — while locals there are fighting back, the concept of paying for a spot on the sand is starting to be seen Down Under.

title.children: 'People are very, very angry': When tourists swamped this island's beaches, locals decided to act

image.altText: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews speaks at a press conference outdoors, he's with Jacinta Allan, Harriet Shing and Jeroen Weimar

items.synopsis: The State of Victoria has agreed to pay the Commonwealth Games parties $380 million in compensation after pulling out of the 2026 regional event.

title.children: Victoria to pay $380 million compensation for cancelling 2026 regional Commonwealth Games

image.altText: The Hancock family in front of a small aircraft

items.synopsis: The portrait of a smiling family captured in 1976 gives little indication of the tensions that would later erupt between the generations — and 40 years later, the feud in the House of Hancock is still firmly in the national spotlight.

title.children: This happy family snap of one of Australia's most prominent families belies the bitter inheritance battle yet to unfold

image.altText: Morris Chang

items.synopsis: The best microchips in the world are made by TSMC. How did it become so important?

title.children: The world's most important company and why everyone wants control of it

image.altText: Sam Kerr stands in a huddle

items.synopsis: The Matildas are determined to take a bronze medal away from the Women's World Cup and coach Tony Gustavsson won't be handing out jerseys.

title.children: 'This is a game to win': Matildas not backing off for third-place play-off

image.altText: Vanessa Comley, a fair-skinned woman, in warm long covered clothes tends to green leafy vegetables at her farm.

items.synopsis: Riverland consumers have another option to access fresh vegetables as a cooperative from the Adelaide Hill expands into new terrain.

title.children: Organic vegetable consumers dig into cooperative alternative in SA's Riverland

image.altText: Outside of the Berri Magistrates Court, the sky is blue and the sign is dark brown.

items.synopsis: A regional South Australian general practitioner alleged to have forged more than 40 prescriptions for opioid medications for personal use faces up to five years in prison.

title.children: GP allegedly uses other doctor's computers for more than 40 opioid prescriptions

image.altText: A Holden ute lifted into the air by a crane

items.synopsis: The Holden ute, worth an estimated $20,000, was reduced to scrap metal by police, about six months after it was clocked at "one of the highest ever speeds" detected on South Australian roads.

title.children: Holden ute previously clocked at 253kph on Adelaide motorway crushed by police

image.altText: Mugshot of a woman with blonde hair

items.synopsis: The jury was told the 33-year-old nurse murdered a set of twins, and told a parent who caught her attacking a baby to "trust me, I'm a nurse".

title.children: 'I am evil': British nurse Lucy Letby found guilty of murdering seven babies

image.altText: A court sketch shows a woman in beige prison uniform sitting next to a man in a suit at a desk

items.synopsis: A court has found neonatal nurse Lucy Letby guilty of murdering the tiny, vulnerable people in her care. The parents of her victims now know who killed their children, but the question of why may forever remain unanswered.

title.children: When this hospital saw a spike in infant deaths, staff noticed unnerving similarities. One nurse was on shift every time

image.altText: a woman smiling and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: New data shows police are increasingly struggling to attend all triple-0 calls, especially those deemed to be less urgent.

title.children: A woman died this week after a delayed police response. New figures highlight a growing problem

image.altText: A man wearing glasses and a suit stands behind a lectern labelled "Working for Australia".

items.synopsis: Two years since the AUKUS deal was announced, the search for a sign that the government has made any progress on working out the details of the nuclear subs emits a sound as hollow as a sonar ping, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Tensions surface as Albanese's ambitions become clear

image.altText: In one image, Donald Trump speaks into a microphone. In another, Young Thug looks in the other direction.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump and rapper Young Thug may appear to have little in common. But both are being charged under the same law, in the same state, by the same prosecutor.

title.children: Young Thug faces the same charge as Donald Trump. And right now, he's sitting in a jail cell

image.altText: A woman with a shaved head smiles

items.synopsis: Breast cancer patients and advocates are decrying a lack of communication about mammograms for women in their 40s, as claims of pushback from services surface.

title.children: This former politician received ‘pushback’ when seeking a mammogram. Her persistence resulted in a diagnosis

image.altText: A man types numbers 365 into a phone calculator with cash and a wallet in the background

items.synopsis: Every time a currency trader or a share investor buys or sells, there's a reason behind it — and the millions of decisions made every day by investors tell a story. The story forming now is one of worry, writes David Taylor.

title.children: 'High risk' of Australian recession as China's property crisis deepens, dollar tumbles

image.altText: A man with black hair and tinted glasses stands on a wooden balcony

items.synopsis: A small Tasmanian town's only GP is quitting, citing burnout, an unsustainable workload and a lack of support from the government. Residents who credit him with saving lives fear what's going to become of local health services.

title.children: Overworked, at risk of burn-out. This town's '24/7' GP is calling it quits

image.altText: Paddy McCartin lies on the ground while a Swans club doctor helps him

items.synopsis: Athletes who sustain concussions are usually quickly pulled from play and have teams of medical professionals overseeing their recoveries. Why aren't victims of domestic violence with brain injuries getting the same care and attention?

title.children: Why isn't the brain injury crisis in our homes causing as much concern as concussion in sport?

image.altText: Magpie profile

items.synopsis: The magpie has something to crow about — it's the winner of our quest to find Australia's most-loved animal sound. But their songs are more than beautiful warbles.

title.children: Magpies warbled their way to the top of our favourite Aussie animal sound poll. So what do their songs mean?

image.altText: Kalpana Khanal appears worried as she stands on a street.

items.synopsis: Analysts say the past 18 months have seen Australia's home construction industry weather one of the largest storms in decades. It's left countless families caught up in builder collapses teetering on the financial brink.

title.children: Kalpana is around the corner from what should be her new home. She can't bring herself to drive past

image.altText: A bushwalker stands in button grass with eyes closed and smiles in the sun

items.synopsis: Rob Parsons is a social media influencer who shares his adventures in the Tasmanian wilderness. But he's just been threatened with legal action by the parks and wildlife service over what he says are outdated filming laws.

title.children: When this adventure filmmaker posted a YouTube video, regulators came calling

image.altText: Matildas players cheer reacting to a penalty shoot out in a large stadium

items.synopsis: Saying the Matildas' performance at the Women's World Cup has changed Australian sport forever, the prime minister promises $200 million for women's sports gear and facilities, plus new broadcasting rules, saying he wants the moment to ripple through generations.

title.children: Seizing the Matildas moment, PM promises $200 million for women's sport

image.altText: Satellite images show entire blocks in Lahaina were razed by fire

items.synopsis: These maps and satellite images show how the Hawaiian town of Lahaina on Maui's west coast has been all but wiped from the map.

title.children: At least 1,719 buildings were destroyed in the Lahaina fire. Satellite images show why that number is set to grow

image.altText: A beachfront scene in Guam, there is green grass, blue skies and palm trees. People are sitting around on deck chairs.

items.synopsis: Expected to cost nearly $8 billion, the defence system being built on Guam is designed to detect and shoot down incoming ballistic, cruise and hypersonic missiles, but not everyone is happy.

title.children: Fears Guam is the 'guinea pig' for a multi-billion-dollar missile defence system

image.altText: the outside of a ford car

items.synopsis: A technical glitch in an online auction led to a car raffle company securing a prized 1976 Ford Falcon Coupe for a "steal" before losing it in a re-run auction.

title.children: 'This is bad': How online auction glitch costs premature bidder classic 1976 Ford

image.altText: Grainy black and white photo of a man and woman standing, while the man holds the woman, and both smile.

items.synopsis: When Michaela Kalowski returned to the town her grandparents were forced from under Hitler, she discovered the powerful way their history is being remembered.

title.children: This town is choosing to acknowledge its horrific past in a powerful way

image.altText: A man looks into the camera in a blue shirt

items.synopsis: Inside Operation Trident — the "complete failure" of a police investigation that created a car-stealing racket and forced one man to fight for decades to clear his name.

title.children: Jack waited 30 years to clear his name after he was arrested as part of an illegal police operation

image.altText: A woman sitting at her desk, with bookshelves in the background, and looking through a thick file of papers.

items.synopsis: The family of a woman killed by her partner almost five years ago has told the coroner that an inquest into her death was the first time they heard the "true story" of what happened to her.

title.children: Lack of resources leads to 'recurring cycle' of domestic violence offending, coroner hears

image.altText: Craig Hamilton thumbnail

items.synopsis: He never planned on becoming a beloved local voice, but Craig Hamilton's career as a broadcaster touched countless sports lovers. After 23 years on air, now he's focusing on mental health advocacy.

title.children: Coal miner, broadcaster, and mental health advocate. Newcastle's Craig Hamilton farewells the ABC

image.altText: Collingwood players stand in a line and look down

items.synopsis: After being blown away by the lethal Brisbane forward line, Collingwood will need to fix up their defensive woes with AFL finals fast approaching.

title.children: 'What is form?' Magpies coach not worried despite Lions exposing defence woes

image.altText: A very young Veronica Milsom wearing a yellow rain jacket and beak portraying The Ugly Duckling for Book Week

items.synopsis: Need to put together a costume on a given theme, with mere minutes notice and almost nothing to work with? I've got you covered.

title.children: Need a quick Book Week costume but have nothing to work with? I've got you

image.altText: Houses in front fire

items.synopsis: Canada's worst fire season on record shows no sign of easing as thousands evacuate from cities under threat of wildfires.

title.children: 'I don't want to die, mommy': 20,000 evacuate from Canadian wildfires

image.altText: A group of donkeys being transported in a truck, close up shot of donkeys

items.synopsis: Eliezer Robinson says demand for these guardians are on the rise after finding them to be fiercely defensive once bonded with a herd, saying "family means everything to them".

title.children: Donkeys are 'natural protectors' and farmers are recruiting them to guard against wild dogs
